title: Lana Del Rey Debuts at No. 1 on Top Album Sales Chart
content:
Plus: Justin Bieber, Loretta Lynn, Jon Batiste, Paul Stanley and Benny the Butcher & Harry Fraud bow in top 10.
Lana Del Rey rules Billboard’s Top Album Sales chart, as her new studio album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club, debuts at No. 1 on the list dated April 3. It’s her third chart-topper on the list, following 2017’s Lust for Life and 2014’s Ultraviolence.
Chemtrails was released March 19 via Polydor/Interscope and starts with 58,000 copies sold in the U.S. in the week ending March 25, according to MRC Data. With Chemtrails’ arrival, Lana Del Rey scores the third-largest sales week for an album released in 2021, and the largest sales week for an album released by a female artist this year. Only the debut frames of Morgan Wallen’s Dangerous: The Double Album (74,000) and Foo Fighters’ Medicine at Midnight (64,000) were larger.
Billboard’s Top Album Sales chart ranks the top-selling albums of the week based only on traditional album sales. The chart’s history dates back to May 25, 1991, the first week Billboard began tabulating charts with electronically monitored piece count information from SoundScan, now MRC Data. Pure album sales were the measurement solely utilized by the Billboard 200 albums chart through the list dated Dec. 6, 2014, after which that chart switched to a methodology that blends album sales with track equivalent album units and streaming equivalent album units. The new April 3-dated Top Album Sales chart (where Chemtrails debuts to No. 1) will be posted in full on Billboard's website on March 30. For all chart news, follow @billboard and @billboardcharts on both Twitter and Instagram.

title: Lana Del Rey Earns Fifth U.K. No. 1 With ‘Chemtrails Over The Country Club’
content:
Lana Del Rey flies high on the U.K. albums chart with Chemtrails Over The Country Club (Polydor), which gives the U.S. singer her fifth No. 1.
Chemtrails bows at the summit with 40,000 chart sales, according to the OCC, a sum that includes a whopping 16,700 sales on vinyl. That’s enough to give Del Rey the fastest-selling vinyl of the century for a female act.
With her latest No. 1 on the Official U.K. Albums Chart, Del Rey ties Celine Dion for the fifth most No. 1 albums by a female solo artist in the U.K. Only Madonna, Kylie Minogue, Barbra Streisand and Taylor Swift have landed more.

title: Lana Del Rey lança novo álbum impressionante
content:
Lana Del Rey (Foto: Neil Krug)
Onde algumas superestrelas se reinventam a cada era, Lana Del Rey prefere refinar seu som e expandir silenciosamente sua personalidade enigmática e infinitamente fascinante.
Co-produzido por Jack Antonoff, que também trabalhou com o cantor de 35 anos em Norman Fucking Rockwell! de 2019, Chemtrails Over the Country Club é outro exercício de precisão e moderação. Os momentos mais fortes do álbum - como um quase rap espetado em Dance Till We Die - parecem fragmentos de luz perfurando as árvores em uma agradável tarde de verão. Mas isso não significa que o sétimo álbum de estúdio de Del Rey seja simplesmente “mais do mesmo”.
Capa do álbum Chemtrails Over The Country Club (Foto: Divulgação)
Aqui estão sete maneiras pelas quais Chemtrails Over The Country Club de Lana Del Rey enriquece seu já formidável legado musical.
1. Del Rey continua a construir seu próprio mito
Um fã hardcore de Del Rey provavelmente poderia escrever uma tese apenas na faixa de abertura White Dress. Aqui, ela relembra seus dias despreocupados pré-fama como uma garçonete que se sentia "vista" por seu homem. Enquanto ela confere o nome das bandas de rock Kings of Leon e The White Stripes - e algo chamado "Men in Music Business Conference" - Del Rey cria um clima íntimo e melancólico que ela mantém pelos próximos 45 minutos ao longo do álbum. A linha final da música é especialmente reveladora e apresenta um dos temas recorrentes do Chemtrails Over The Country Club: quando Del Rey canta, "meio que me faz sentir que talvez eu estivesse melhor", ela parece estar sugerindo que a fama também não esteve gratificante para ela.
2. Ela definitivamente tem fama em mente
Del Rey nos diz exatamente o que ela pensa da fama em Dark But Just a Game quando canta, "está escuro, mas é apenas um jogo - então toque como uma sinfonia". Wild at Heart - uma canção que divide o título com um filme de David Lynch de 1990, um toque muito Del Rey - realmente se inclina para a sombra. Quando ela canta "as câmeras têm flashes, elas causam os acidentes de carro", é difícil não imaginar a falecida princesa Diana, um ícone cujo nome Del Rey conferiu em seu poema Patent Leather Do-Over.
3. Encontra novos giros no ritmo normal e lânguido de Del Rey
Agora, os fãs dela sabem que não devem esperar cortes agitados - para isso, você precisará revisitar os remixes de 2013 prontos para clubes de Cedric Gervais de Summertime Sadness e Young & Beautiful. Como todos os álbuns desde Ultraviolence de 2014, Chemtrails Over The Country Club é uma peça de humor, mas isso não significa que falte luz e sombra. Breaking Up Slowly é uma balada com salpicos country, Dance Till We Die apresenta algumas trompas jazzísticas e Wild At Heart tem vocais overdubbed impressionantes que farão seus braços se arrepiarem.
Consistentemente melódico e meticulosamente produzido, este é um álbum que revela floreios sutis e detalhes ocultos a cada toque.
Lana no clipe Chemtrails Over The Country Club (Foto: Cortesia )
4. Ela nos lembra que ela ainda é uma romântica incurável
Não seria um álbum de Lana Del Rey sem pelo menos um interesse amoroso não confiável, mas sedutor. Ele aparece em Not All Who Wander Are Lost, puxando cadeiras e abrindo portas para Del Rey como um verdadeiro cavalheiro. Isso não significa, no entanto, que ela se sinta totalmente convencida por ele. "O que acontece com homens como você é que você tem muito a dizer", ela canta, "mas você vai ficar?"
5. Ela também nos lembra que é uma das grandes compositoras americanas
“Eu venho de uma cidade pequena, e você? Só menciono isso porque estou pronto para deixar LA”, Del Rey canta em Let Me Love You Like a Woman. Nessa música, ela está presa entre as luzes brilhantes do sonho americano e suas raízes mais discretas. Embora ela tenha nascido em Manhattan, sua família mudou-se para Lake Placid, uma pequena cidade no interior do estado de Nova York, quando ela tinha um ano.
Em outro lugar, Tulsa Jesus Freak combina sexo e religião de uma forma que lembra o Cinturão Bíblico conservador dos Estados Unidos. "Devíamos voltar para o Arkansas", canta Del Rey, "trocar este corpo por aquela lata de gim."
Cena do clipe Chemtrails Over The Country Club (Foto: Cortesia )
6. As letras são salpicadas de referências nostálgicas da cultura pop
Tulsa Jesus Freak e Yosemite pegaram emprestadas as imagens da Candle in the Wind de Elton John, enquanto Del Rey pisca para Prince em Let Me Love You Like a Woman, quando canta: "Podemos nos perder na chuva roxa." Mais tarde, a cantora country Nikki Lane colabora no adorável Breaking Up Slowly e entrega este dístico nítido: "Não quero viver uma vida de arrependimento / Não quero terminar como Tammy Wynette."
7. E termina com uma capa de Joni Mitchell
Depois de cantar na penúltima faixa Dance Till We Die que ela está "fazendo um cover de Joni", Del Rey faz exatamente isso, recrutando os cantores indie Weyes Blood e Zella Day para uma interpretação sincera da faixa de 1970 de Joni Mitchell For Free. É fácil ver como há um destaque do álbum Ladies Of The Canyon, que pode ressoar com Del Rey. É uma música na qual Mitchell pondera a diferença entre ela mesma - uma estrela cantando suas canções "para fortunas" e "chamadas de cortina de veludo" - e uma humilde musicista de rua que ela vê tocando "muito bem" por nenhum dinheiro.
Não pela primeira vez neste álbum, Del Rey parece estar se perguntando se ela estava “melhor” antes de se tornar famosa.
Chemtrails Over The Country Club de Lana Del Rey já está disponível nas plataformas digitais

title: Lana Del Rey: Albumtitel schon geplant
content:
Die Sängerin sagte der ‚Music Week‘: „Weil ich so viel Zeit in einem engen Kreis von Country-Musik-Freunden verbringe, konnte ich eine Option für einen Titel sehen, der daraus kommt. Ich habe auch einen alternativen Titel, den ich mag, der 18 Monate meines Lebens zusammenfasst.“ Für welchen sie sich entscheiden wird, werden die Fans aber wohl noch nicht sofort erfahren.
Die 35-Jährige hat auch erklärt, dass sie sich nicht darauf konzentriere, riesige ‚Hit‘-Singles zu schreiben, sondern interessante Projekte schaffen wolle. Sie fügte hinzu: „Es ist nicht so, dass ich keinen Hit haben will. Es ist nur so, dass meine Reise, ohne es direkt zu planen, eher zu einem langfristigen Spiel geworden ist.“
BANG Showbiz

title: DN Kultur väljer fem favoriter bland aktuella verk vecka 12
content:
Foto: Universal Music
Album. Lana Del Rey, ”Chemtrails over the country club”
Universal Music
”I'm ready to leave LA”, sjunger Lana Del Rey vemodigt i låten ”Let me love you like a woman”, om den soldränkta staden som hon alltid har dyrkat, inte minst på 2019 års album ”Norman fucking Rockwell!”. På nya ”Chemtrails over the country club” har något förändrats. Över avskalade och akustiska produktioner kontemplerar hon över det lilla livet och sin tonårstid. Hon namndroppar artister som Stevie Nicks och Joan Baez, gör en rysligt vacker cover på Joni Mitchell och det är tydligt att hon vill associeras med 70-talets folkmusiklegendarer hellre än dagens glättiga popvärld. Det är en position som passar henne väldigt bra.
Kajsa Haidl
Elin Cullhed Foto: Sofia Runarsdotter
Roman. Elin Cullhed, ”Eufori”
Albert Bonniers förlag
Det kan ju tyckas dödsföraktande att ge sig på att skriva en roman om Sylvia Plath som så många har ett starkt förhållande till. Ändå har Elin Cullhed gjort just det. Och att hennes första bok för vuxna är så upplyftande beror på att hon vågat kasta loss från verklighetens Plath. Här finns fakta från den ikoniska författarens sista år – med maken Ted Hughes, barnen, huset i Devon – men utifrån det skapar Cullhed en fri fantasi. Med sprakande bilder, stora känslor och ett intensivt språk skriver hon en småmanisk berättelse om kvinnors och mäns skapande. Lika sann som hjärtskärande.
Åsa Beckman
Bild 1 av 2 Cecilia Germain, ”Delta Theta Alpha”. Foto: Hanna Ukura Bild 2 av 2 Vy från Cecilia Germains utställning Foto: Hanna Ukura Bildspel
Utställning. Cecilia Germain, ”The dream keeper”
Bokyrka konsthall, Fittja
”The dream keeper” på Botkyrka konsthall är Cecilia Germains första soloutställning. Det är en poetisk och multisensorisk presentation, som förutom synen även stimulerar hörseln, lukt- och smaksinnet. Konstnären bjuder dessutom in lokalbefolkningen till att bygga upp ett kollektivt herbarium och har själv tagit med sig krukväxter som alla har afrikanska rötter. Utställningen tar avstamp i faderns släkt som drabbades av den transatlantiska slavhandeln och berör på olika sätt denna mörka historia med förflyttningar över tid och kontinenter. Men smärtan får sällskap av framtidsdrömmar och Germain visar fint hur läkning kan gå till.
Birgitta Rubin
Vigdis Hjorth. Foto: Chris Maluszynski
Roman. Vigdis Hjorth, ”Är mor död”
Natur & Kultur, övers. Jens Hjälte
Varje ny roman av Vigdis Hjorth är en händelse: vilken känsla ska man nu få följa från första impulsen till uppgörelsens katastrof? I ”Är mor död” försöker bildkonstnären Johanna, snart 60 år, få tillbaka kontakten med sin mamma, som brutit med dottern efter en rad konflikter. Och från det att Johanna lite försiktigt söker efter sin mammas nya adress, till dess att romanen närmar sig sitt slut, har en utdragen explosion skett. Vigdis Hjorths romaner upprättar en förbindelse mellan det grekiska ödesdramat och den moderna psykologin. Det blir storartad litteratur, med ett språk som få läsaren att andas i takt med texten. Har jag sagt att hon är rolig också?
Malin Ullgren
Josefin Asplund i ”Snöänglar”. Foto: Johan Paulin /SVT
Tv-serie. ”Snöänglar”
SVT
Svensk tv-drama tycks ha prickat en ny formtopp. På söndag kommer dramaserien som kommer att fylla tomrummet efter ”Tunna blå linjen”. Allt börjar med en mardröm på julaftonsmorgon när Josefin Asplunds pillermissbrukande småbarnsmamman vaknar upp ur dimman och upptäcker att hennes nyfödda son är spårlöst försvunnen. Ur detta kommer ett känsloladdat, nervigt och levande drama som rör sig i gränslandet mellan socialdrama och kriminalthriller. Eller som Jacob Lundström skrev i sin recension: ”En både inkännande och spännande helvetesresa.” Lysande rollprestationer av bland andra Josefin Asplund, Ardalan Esmaili, Eva Melander och Cecilia Nilsson.
Nicholas Wennö

title: Lana Del Rey feels nostalgic for 2004 in the stunning 'White Dress'
content:
A stark but beautiful reflection on what was a much simpler time for the artist
Every day we highlight great new music added to the Double J playlist.
New to Double J? Here's how you can tune in, no matter where you are.
Lana Del Rey's new album Chemtrails Over The Country Club opens with 'White Dress', a gentle piano ballad that see the singer reflect on a simpler world. A world where she was a 19-year-old waitress obsessed with The White Stripes and Kings Of Leon.
Skip YouTube Video FireFox NVDA users - To access the following content, press 'M' to enter the iFrame.
Of course, it's not as breezy as all that might make it sound. There's a conflict here, as Lana considers whether she left behind a better life when she pursued the dream of stardom.
"What I like about that song is that for all of its weirdness, when you get to the end of it, you understand exactly what it’s about," she told collaborator Jack Antonoff in Interview Magazine last year.
"I hate when I hear a song that has a great melody, but I have no idea what they’re talking about."
Fame can be a burden. Fame like Del Rey's, which has been complex since the very start and isn't getting any simpler, must feel particularly encumbering.
For all the justified criticism she gets for some of her public comments, this song proves she is able to express herself in song pretty incredibly.
Also, the vocal hook in the chorus is simply stunning.
Chemtrails Over The Country Club is out now.
Check out Double J's Best New Music playlists on Spotify and Apple Music for more great new tunes.

title: Noah Cyrus Signs With TaP Music for Management
content:
"We have been fans from afar for a long time," Millet tells Billboard. "We were finally introduced, had an initial meeting over Zoom and then when Wendy and Mookie met Noah in person it all clicked and moved fast."
Adds Cyrus: "Immediately upon meeting Mookie and Wendy, I knew TaP would be my new home. I’m thrilled to be joining a roster with such strong female artists who are empowered to achieve massive success on their own terms.”
Earlier this month, Cyrus, 21, attended the Grammys as a best new artist nominee. Last year, she released her well-received, more stripped-down EP, The End of Everything, on RECORDS/Columbia. She's currently working on a six-track project with collaborator PJ Harding as well as her upcoming debut full-length.

title: Lana Del Rey’s 10-Year War With the Culture
content:
2020 was a treacherous year for celebrities online, who had to navigate a complex set of unwritten rules about the proper tone to strike on social media that bedeviled even the savviest among them. So of course Del Rey wasted no time stepping in it. In May, she announced her new album with an Instagram post: “Now that Doja Cat, Ariana [Grande], Camila [Cabello], Cardi B, Kehlani, Nicki Minaj, and Beyoncé have had number ones with songs about being sexy, wearing no clothes, fucking, cheating, etc. — can I please go back to singing about being embodied, feeling beautiful by being in love even if the relationship is not perfect, or dancing for money … without being crucified or saying that I’m glamorizing abuse? … I’m not not a feminist, but there has to be a place in feminism for women who look and act like me.” The other artists’ fans united against her, pointing out that she’d mostly targeted women of color. Del Rey’s own fans pleaded for her to delete the post. A more calculating star might have known it was time to go away for a while. But it was 2020 — who was capable of logging off? Instead, she dug in her heels. “The fact that they want to turn … my advocacy for fragility into a race war — it’s really bad,” she said in a follow-up video. Her timing was impeccable: That same week, the Amy Cooper scandal turned white women’s “fragility” into a punch line.
Photo: Lana Del Rey/Instagram An Instagram message to her fans.
Del Rey tried to get back on the right side of history, but once again she was playing with imagery whose meaning had slipped out of her grasp. When she Instagrammed L.A. protests against police brutality, she drew criticism for posting videos of looting. When she did a book signing wearing a mesh mask, she was accused of putting lives at risk. (She claimed it had protective plastic underneath.) Eventually she entered a state of twitchy paranoia familiar to listeners of Taylor Swift’s Reputation. After posting the art for her upcoming album, Del Rey appended a defense against accusations of tokenism that had yet to be made: “As it happens when it comes to my amazing friends and this cover, yes, there are people of color on this record’s picture.” She added, “My best friends are rappers, my boyfriends have been rappers.”
She was not entirely wrong to be so anxious. The following day, Del Rey proposed to an interviewer that Trump was so addled before the January 6 insurrection that “he doesn’t know that he’s inciting a riot” — and was immediately accused of downplaying the violence. Unhappy with the way her comments were circulated online, she personally responded to seemingly every single tweet about it, taking particular umbrage with Complex. “It’s fucked up. You know I’m real,” she tweeted at the website, whose audience has primarily been people of color. Shortly after Chemtrails’ release in March, she sarcastically reposted a months-old Harper’s Bazaar think piece: “Just want to say thank you again for the kind articles like this one and for reminding me that my career was built on cultural appropriation and glamorizing domestic abuse.” Then she announced she would soon be releasing yet another album: Rock Candy Sweet, out June 1.
Thus, the negative feedback loop rolls on. Every stilted and tone-deaf public statement brings less charity from the blogosphere, which only makes her skin even thinner. There are two ways the relationship can go from here: If the albums hold up, Del Rey’s artistry could push away the memory of a few bad posts. If it’s not, we all may be better served muting her for a while.

title: Soprano, Justin Bieber, Lana Del Rey...Le top clips de la semaine

title: Le romantisme épuré de la chanteuse Lana Del Rey
content:
La chanteuse Lana Del Rey, en juillet 2020, à Los Angeles. NEIL KRUG
Lèvres rouges pulpeuses en évidence, faux cils et eye-liner pour la touche gothique, gilet à carreaux grunge et attelle à la main gauche pour le soupçon de dérision, Lana Del Rey pose en « une » du nouveau numéro du magazine britannique Mojo. Un nouveau gage de crédibilité pour la diva pop californienne de 35 ans, ce mensuel rock étant plutôt habitué aux couvertures posthumes sur Bowie, Cohen et Lennon ou des légendes vivantes sexagénaires. Dans l’entretien, le seul accordé à la presse, la chanteuse confie que les nombreuses interviews données lors des quatre premières années de sa célébrité l’ont littéralement « cramée ».
Il faut dire que la critique, divisée, n’a pas toujours été tendre avec Elizabeth Woolridge Grant (son vrai nom à l’état civil) depuis le raz-de-marée provoqué par son tube Video Games en 2012. Lana Del Rey affirme dans Mojo s’être souvent sentie humiliée par des questions lourdes de sous-entendus hautains, lorsque les journalistes la soupçonnaient d’être une starlette fabriquée par les maisons de disques – ce qui est faux.
Lire le portrait (en septembre 2019) : Le rêve américain selon Lana Del Rey
Sept albums plus tard, elle a prouvé que son talent n’était pas éphémère. Disciplinée créativement, discrète sur sa vie privée, Lana Del Rey enregistre des albums à cadence annuelle, une prolificité qui lui permet de s’autoriser quelques écarts artistiques sans trop de conséquences. Après un passage à vide entre 2015 et 2018, son sixième opus, Norman Fucking Rockwell (2019) a été encensé et auréolé du Grammy du meilleur album. Depuis a été a publié, en septembre 2020, un disque à part, Violet Bent Backwards Over the Grass, recueil de ses poésies mis en musique. Un privilège rare dans un environnement mainstream dominé par les musiques urbaines.
Compositions dépouillées
Chemtrails Over the Country Club, septième album, prolonge cette phase créative sans souffler sur les braises du succès du précédent. Les onze chansons ont été produites et coécrites avec Jack Antonoff, découvert par Taylor Swift et partenaire de jeu depuis Norman Fucking Rockwell. En quarante minutes, le disque est le plus court de Lana Del Rey, volonté d’élagage que l’on retrouve dans des compositions relativement dépouillées. « Nous avons retiré des choses, encore et encore, jusqu’à trouver l’essence de Chemtrails Over the Country Club », a commenté Jack Antonoff sur Instagram. L’enregistrement a été très spontané lors de sessions confinées au studio new-yorkais Electric Lady : « Des prises principalement en direct, alors que les choses venaient juste d’être écrites. Des chansons comme White Dress et Not All Who Wander Are Lost reflètent ces premiers moments où mots et musique prennent ensemble subitement forme. »
Il vous reste 39.74% de cet article à lire. La suite est réservée aux abonnés.

title: Lana Del Rey no conduce coches eléctricos
content:
Nadie ejemplifica mejor que Lana Del Rey la escisión vivida en el seno de la generación millennial en el último par de años. Analizada hasta el último detalle en infinidad de artículos, ensayos y tuits, se convirtió tal vez en la generación más monitorizada de la historia. Obviamente, como ese control era ejercido mayormente por miembros de generaciones anteriores, se convirtieron también en la menos comprensible. Pero los analistas, y también ese segmento de la población que transita por la vida con complejo de audiencia, se cansaron de ellos.
Dedicaron todas sus energías a los que venían detrás. Una parte de los millennials se erigieron en portavoces de la generación Z, al menos, en los medios —prensa, Twitter, Instagram— en los que estos no tenían presencia ni ganas de tenerla. Otra se aferró a la nostalgia prematura, aquello que decían los expertos que los definía. Lana Del Rey es de estos últimos. Como buena millennial, pasó casi una década siendo observada, puesta en duda, elevada a la categoría de única y sin precedentes y también a la de redundante, egocéntrica y algo pedante. Hasta 2019, cuando lanzó Norman Fucking Rockwell!, cada triunfo de la estadounidense cargaba la misma cantidad de éxito que de fracaso. Aquel disco lo cambió todo. Porque era espectacular, pero también porque lo que ella significaba —en tanto a ella misma y en tanto a su generación— ya importaba menos. Dos años después, aparece Chemtrails Over The Country Club, un álbum que Lana Del Rey anunció prácticamente el mismo día que lanzó el anterior. Parecía que quisiera aprovechar que entonces prensa y público parecían alineados con lo que ella proponía y no tanto ya con lo que ellos proponían para ella. Pero ese disco se hizo tan grande y tan influyente que la californiana dejó de tener prisa. Por eso tal vez este álbum caminó tan despacio.
Chemtrails Over The Country Club mantiene algunas de las constantes de Norman Fucking Rockwell!, pero es mucho más tímido, una característica que jamás creíamos que podríamos asociar a su autora. El disco arranca con la estupenda ‘White Dress’, que narra su experiencia como camarera en una convención de la industria del disco. No puede evitar recordar lo fácil que era todo cuando simplemente podías ir por la vida escuchando a The White Stripes. El tema es una maravilla nerviosa en la que las palabras se caen unas encima de las otras, mientras ella trata de ordenarlas con pavorosa tranquilidad. Es tremendamente gratificante escuchar cómo el corte se embarulla. Algo similar sucede en ‘Dark but Just a Game’, tal vez la canción más cercana a Norman Fucking Rockwell!, en la que se juega más.
El resto del disco apuesta por una aproximación más de perfil bajo. Hay que buscar más los detalles que en las anteriores entregas. Cuando los encuentras, eso sí, son tremendamente bellos. Desde la cadencia perfectamente armada del tema titular hasta esa batalla entre ella y Jack Antonoff que es ‘Tulsa Jesus Freak’, pasando por la forma en que la pareja de artista y productor parecen reparar a medio camino en que ‘Wild at Heart’ es un corte que ya han grabado y empiezan a retorcerlo hasta convertirlo en algo soberbio y hasta novedoso, o la versión del ‘For Free’ de Joni Mitchell que, con la colaboración de Weyes Blood y Zella Day, cierra el disco y que sirve para desenmascarar todos los trucos del álbum y hasta de la toda la carrera de la californiana. Como Lana Del Rey es una prestidigitadora sin pudor, desenmarscararla le sienta mejor a ella que a quien cree desenmascararla.
Portada de 'Chemtrails Over the Country Club', de Lana Del Rey. AP
Toda la iconografía asociada a la estadounidense ha tenido siempre mucho que ver con una idea de EE UU que ya casi no existe y que apenas ella parece echar de menos. Su visión tiene cero sintonía con los tiempos que corren, porque sus ciudades no son cosmopolitas y liberales o convulsas y apocalípticas, sino bellas, trágicas y ensimismadas. Sus personajes pertenecen a cierto concepto de élite blanca que ya no se celebra ni en las revistas de moda y sus inquietudes producen imágenes preciosas que nada tienen que ver con casi nada que pueda sucederle a nadie. Un coche descapotable es un coche que te pueden robar, no uno en el que lo peor que te puede pasar es que te despeines.
En ese universo que ha creado, a pesar de ser un mundo que tiene los días contados, Lana del Rey está cómoda porque sabe gestionar la melancolía como nadie, aportando una pizca de rencor y otra de humor. Sus personajes no toman cócteles de narcóticos, sino que se toman los narcóticos como si fueran cócteles. El problema llega cuando Lana abandona la comodidad de su visión californiana de la tragedia en Cinemascope y se adentra en el interior de EE UU. Temas como ‘Yosemite’ y ‘Not All Who Wander Are Lost’ son ejercicios folk soporíferos, vacíos de valor y con un discurso que no termina de funcionar. Como todo en Lana Del Rey, depende de lo cómoda que se encuentre ella en su decepción y su ensoñación. Llevarla hasta un sitio en el que tiene que cerrar los ojos para ver algo resulta un fracaso tremendo. Lo único bueno que se atisba en este camino emprendido por la artista hacia lo rural es que, cuando escriba sobre su retorno a casa, con el rímel corrido, la factura del motel sin pagar, la maleta con la mitad de las cosas que contenía cuando salió de casa y el coche sin apenas gasolina (Lana no conduce eléctricos), los resultados pueden ser espectaculares.
Puedes seguir a BABELIA en Facebook y Twitter, o apuntarte aquí para recibir nuestra newsletter semanal.

title: „Chemtrails“: Eine philologische Lektüre von Lana del Rey
content: „Die beste Maske, die wir tragen, ist unser eigenes Gesicht“, schrieb Nietzsche einmal. Eine Dialektik der künstlerischen Maske liegt darin, dass gerade sie die Mitteilung jener verletzlichen, weichen Zonen ermöglicht, die wir Normal-Maskierten berechtigterweise so ängstlich verbergen. Was wäre es auch anderes als Schamlosigkeit? Privatsphäre hat ihren Sinn. Lassen wir also Elizabeth Grant, von der wir so wenig wissen, beiseite, und lauschen wir Lana Del Rey, wie sie auf ihrem neuen, sechsten Studioalbum erscheint.

title: With her sixth album Chemtrails Over the Country Club, Lana Del Rey takes a road trip into the past
content:
Like much of Lana Del Rey's music, #Chemtrails often bends backward to grasp at an elusive and irretrievable prelapsarian state
On her sixth major-label album, Chemtrails Over the Country Club, Lana Del Rey wants to get away from it all.
After her great, California-centric 2019 epic Norman _____ Rockwell! maybe she’s just craving a change of scenery: “I’m ready to leave LA and I want you to come,” she announces on the new album’s wanderlustful first single, 'Let Me Love You Like a Woman.' Other Chemtrails songs name-check stops on an American road trip, from Yosemite National Park to Lincoln, Nebraska, to Tulsa, Oklahoma. But on some of the record’s most stirring moments, Del Rey seems to desire an even greater spiritual sense of oblivion: “I’m in the wind, I’m in the water, nobody’s son, nobody’s daughter,” she sings on the haunting title track, sounding blissfully untethered. During the album’s opening number, 'White Dress,' she pirouettes across the upper edge of her vocal register, her airy falsetto evaporating into the space around her like a fleeting, soon-to-be-illegible piece of skywriting.
One of the album’s several stunners, 'White Dress' is a melancholic, piano-driven tone poem that conjures the emotional intensity of Cat Power and reimagines a “simpler time” when the narrator was a 19-year-old night-shift server in — of all the places in Norman Rockwell’s America — Orlando, Florida. But she felt happy, capable: “When I was a server, wearing a white dress, like look how I do it, look how I got this.” The tempo is unhurried, and the song saves some of its most affecting revelations — “it kind of makes me feel like maybe I was better off” — for its unsettling final moments.
From the moment she emerged with the semi-anachronistic torch song 'Video Games' in 2011, Del Rey has always branded herself an old soul. Like much of her music, Chemtrails often bends backward to grasp at an elusive and irretrievable prelapsarian state. (As she put it on one of her best songs, 2019’s unofficial anthem 'The Greatest,' “nobody warns you before the fall.”) Sometimes the past she glorifies is mass-cultural (the muted, subtly auto-tuned 'Tulsa Jesus Freak' mines a Manson-family aesthetic similar to Quentin Tarantino’s Once Upon a Time … in Hollywood), but just as often on this record it is sharply personal, yearning for a lost time when making music was a carefree hobby and not Del Rey’s job. Throughout, Chemtrails finds her meditating on the value of her art, wondering if it’s too late to get back to the garden.
Fame is the album’s recurring boogeyman, most explicitly on the languidly guitar-driven 'Dark but Just a Game,' which Del Rey has said takes its name from something her producer Jack Antonoff said to her while they were musing about the tragic fates of so many stars. (Chemtrails reunites Del Rey with Antonoff, who coproduced Norman with her and once again gives her billowing voice the appropriate amount of compositional elbow room.) “The cameras have flashes, they cause the car crashes,” she sings on the gently surging 'Wild at Heart' — another highlight. On two other occasions she references 'Candle in the Wind,' that mass-cult elegy that Elton John barely needed to rework to fit the fates of both Marilyn Monroe and Princess Diana.
Easy as it can be to forget, though, the particular slab of blue over the country club is hardly the entire sky. This finite perspective makes Chemtrails more of a minor offering than Norman _____ Rockwell!, which took big swings and often connected, capturing something that had been difficult to articulate about her generation’s larger sense of malaise. Perhaps to avoid repeating herself, Chemtrails finds Del Rey scaling back, seeking more insular insight.
When all of its virtues are working in tandem — rich melodies, compositional surprises, only-Lana-would-say-it turns of phrase — Del Rey’s music casts an engrossing spell. But in the moments when its tempos and timbres grow a bit repetitive, as they did on her sleepy 2015 album Honeymoon and do for a several-song stretch in the middle of this album, its limitations come into focus. 'Not All Who Wander Are Lost' builds a chorus around bumper-sticker wisdom, while vague lyrics like “let me love you like a woman, let me hold you like a baby” lack the specificity of her better songs.
At best, Del Rey’s hyper-referential music convincingly recreates the particular feeling of encountering art in a postmodern age, when the past is so cluttered with worthwhile cultural artefacts that everything new reminds one, at least a little bit, of something old. But as she dances on that fine line between evoking and signifying, Del Rey sometimes risks outsourcing her profundity to things other artists have said more vividly before.
Such is the gamble of ending an album with a Joni Mitchell cover — though here that’s a risk Del Rey pulls off. On a gorgeous, reverent and harmony-enlivened rendition of 'For Free,' she is joined by the musicians Zella Day and Natalie Mering (who records as Weyes Blood), and in Mitchell’s lines finds echoes with many of the questions she’s been pondering about the relative value of art and the distortions of fame. The song comes from Mitchell’s 1970 LP Ladies of the Canyon, but if Chemtrails has a kindred spirit in Mitchell’s discography, it’s 1972’s For the Roses, her own “leaving Los Angeles” album, which Mitchell composed in the solitude of her stone cottage on the Sunshine Coast of British Columbia.
By the end of Chemtrails, though, Del Rey has found solace not in solitude but solidarity, specifically with other women. The album regains momentum on its final trio of songs, which are suddenly populated with other female voices and names. (In addition to Day and Mering on 'For Free,' Del Rey is joined by the country artist Nikki Lane on a song Lane wrote, 'Breaking Up Slowly.') The cathartic 'Dancing Til We Die' finds her doing a late-night Louisiana two-step with an imagined clique of her musical heroes, some of whom (Stevie Nicks, Joan Baez) Del Rey has already toured or collaborated with. “God, it feels good not to be alone,” she exhales, shortly before the faint, lonely sound of a horn drifts into the mix, as if from another bar down the road. Momentarily, it leaves its mark in the blue, and then just as quickly it’s gone.
Lindsay Zoladz c. 2021 The New York Times Company

title: Chemtrails Over The Country Club shows us the real Lana Del Rey
content:
Dialling back the drama, the album serves as a love letter to the past, but one that feels more genuine to Lana herself.
In the ten years since Lana Del Rey first introduced us to her world of ‘Video Games’, she’s perfected tragic Hollywood romanticism. A greyscale chase of an American Dream, driven by a love of vintage glamour and beautiful melancholia.
From Born to Die to Ultraviolence, then Lust For Life into her acclaimed Norman F*cking Rockwell! chapter, the intrigue surrounding Lana Del Rey and her next steps has always remained enticing.
Enter: Chemtrails Over The Country Club.
Lana Del Rey has always been at her best when writing about the subject she knows most intimately: herself. These tracks were laden with the self-indulgence fans have come to expect from Lana, but with a sense of reinvention threaded throughout both.
Chemtrails… swaps SoCal confidence and braggadocio for folkier hues and ballads built against sparse, minimal arrangement. Working with Jack Antonoff and Rick Nowels on production, Lana opts to put a more emotional perspective front and centre the whole way through - a perspective that seems more connected to her actual self, than any other character adopted previously.
Skip YouTube Video FireFox NVDA users - To access the following content, press 'M' to enter the iFrame.
‘White Dress’, with its references to Kings of Leon and The White Stripes, is the type of song that invites Lana fans to look on at moments where she began that transition from youth into adulthood.
“When I was a waitress / Wearing a tight dress / Handling the heat
I wasn’t famous / Just listening to / Kings of Leon to the beat
Like look at how / I got this / Look how I / Got this”
It’s a strong start to the record, bolstered by ‘Chemtrails Over The Country Club’ and ‘Wild At Heart’, both offering up some of the album’s most melodic moments. It’s made evident that Chemtrails… is more about the small town experiences, the formative moments that can form character.
Gone is Lana’s focus on the sun-kissed West Coast. Instead, she‘s powered by the spirits of Joan Baez and Joni Mitchell, drawing inspiration from the American Midwest.
Stylistically, Chemtrails… doesn’t veer too much away from understated balladry, but when it does, it provides moments of sharpness and renewed clarity. ‘Dark But Just A Game’ is a great switch up; seductive in its slow burn guitars and tambourine.
Skip YouTube Video FireFox NVDA users - To access the following content, press 'M' to enter the iFrame.
Lana meditates on fame, and her disillusionment with it, rather wishing for people to stay the same.
“It’s dark / But just a game
So play it / Like a symphony
You know / Our love’s the same
They’ll both go down / In infamy”
It’s a central idea we hear again on ‘Yosemite’, with Lana singing about change in seasons and relationships with a wryness that feels quite personal. It’s the sort of music you listen to and could easily associate with the cinematic sounds of her previous work. Here, Lana’s voice is simply accompanied by acoustic guitar, minimal percussion and delicate production. And it works way better.
The second half of Chemtrails…, though it does have ‘Yosemite’ and ‘Dance Till We Die’, does become same-y. ‘Not All Who Wander Are Lost’ and ‘Breaking Up Slowly’, though not placed together on the tracklist, feel like they bleed into one another.
Closing the album with a cover of Joni Mitchell’s 1970 classic ‘For Free’, Lana recruits the talents of both Zella Day and Weyes Blood to flesh it out. And it has to be said, Weyes Blood’s Joni-isms on this track are scarily accurate. It’s a surprising moment of contrast, but one I’m glad exists.
Skip YouTube Video FireFox NVDA users - To access the following content, press 'M' to enter the iFrame.
Chemtrails Over The Country Club is easily one of the most delicate Lana Del Rey efforts to date. Her songwriting feels more introspective than wide-eyed and wandering. The lyricism rolls off the tongue as if her diary entries have been taken from the page direct to record.
Is it her most inspired collection of material? No.
Is it any less magnetic? Definitely not.
And it’s this paradoxical element of Lana Del Rey’s artistry that makes her a compelling figure, whether you want to wade into her world or not.
Just days after the album’s release, Lana announced another album - Rock Sweet Candy - is on the way in June. The way Lana has promoted its release so far makes it seem like a direct commentary on the backlash she received following distasteful doubled down responses to allegations of cultural appropriation.
You listen to an album like Chemtrails… then read Lana’s social media post about ‘wanting revenge’ - the two are baffling to put together. But maybe we’re not supposed to.
Lana’s brilliance as a songwriter has always stemmed from the way she creates a universe all her own on record, so who knows what is coming next.

title: Lana Del Rey’s ‘Chemtrails’ Is Flying to No. 1 In U.K.
content:
Lana Del Rey is cruising to a fifth No. 1 on the U.K. Albums Chart with Chemtrails Over The Country Club (Polydor).
At the halfway point in the chart week, the U.S. singer and songwriter’s latest LP is outselling the rest of the Top 10 combined, the OCC reports.
Chemtrails is the best-seller in physical and digital formats so far this cycle. Its midweek tally of 34,000 combined sales eclipses the entire first-week effort of her previous three albums, and the collection is on track for Del Rey’s best release week since 2014’s Ultraviolence.

title: ‘Chemtrails Over the Country Club’ by Lana Del Rey Review: Tainted by Expectation
content:
In 2011, singer Lana Del Rey released “Video Games,” a single that introduced her to the wider public but was not her debut. She’d already issued a digital EP as Lizzy Grant in 2008 and a full-length album introducing her new moniker in 2010 (albeit with a different spelling than she now uses), “ Lana Del Ray A.K.A. Lizzy Grant.” But these releases, when she was still tethered to her birth name, were heard by almost no one and have been written out of her canon. From “Video Games” forward, she wrote about star-crossed lovers moving through scenes dense with references to film and music history and sang her songs in a whispered croon that radiated glamour. This shadowy mode became synonymous with her stage name and her music, which sold and streamed in big numbers, and carried her to widespread fame.
On her 2019 record “Norman F—ing Rockwell!” she shared her tales of existential romance at the edge of the apocalypse, and they attained an extra layer of meaning because of who was singing them. While her songs unfold like little movies and can carry psychological insight, they also touch on what it’s like to be Lana Del Rey. “NFR!” topped many critics’ lists in 2019 and was a clear breakthrough for the singer, so following it was inevitably going to be tricky. Her seventh studio album, “Chemtrails Over the Country Club,” out now, sounds similar to its predecessor on a casual listen and features a few new wrinkles, but it’s missing the detail that makes her best work so remarkable.
Musically, “Chemtrails” extends the sound of “NFR!” Once again, she mostly works with songwriter and producer Jack Antonoff, who co-writes and co-produces almost all of the material— Rick Nowels, her creative partner on earlier work, writes and produces one track. As in 2019, the tempos are slow and the arrangements are minimalist, led by piano or acoustic guitar.
The most appealing twists here are her experiments with vocals. She’s become a more resourceful singer over the years, and on many of these tracks she uses the upper end of her range in novel ways, conveying new vulnerability. The opener, “White Dress,” finds her in this mode. It’s one of her best songs to date, looking back at her life at age 19—she’s 35 now—when she was waiting tables and living in the moment with no hint of what was to come. She’s always had an ear for lyrical specificity, and here she name-checks two emerging rock bands from that time—“Listening to White Stripes when they were white-hot” and “I wasn’t famous, just listening to Kings of Leon”—and positions herself as a dreamer who had a lot to learn about navigating the music business but had the tenacity to succeed.
The higher voice that carries through “White Dress” pops up regularly on “Chemtrails,” and we’ve never heard her sound quite like this before. On “NFR!” she often sounded dryly amused and sometimes even bored by the parade of men in her life, and her offhand put-downs added moments of levity. Here, singing with a more fragile tone, she sounds like someone for whom a potentially doomed affair represents a real risk.
A handful of recurring images and motifs suggest a loose concept. Both “Tulsa Jesus Freak,” which indulges Ms. Del Rey’s fascination with love and lust among the down-and-out, and “Yosemite,” about a romantic pair who seal themselves off from the world and become obsessed with each other, contain the phrase “No more candle in the wind,” which is nearly identical to a line from her 2018 epic “Mariner’s Apartment Complex.” The use of the line is quintessential Lana Del Rey, taking an overexposed element from pop culture—in this case, Elton John’s 1973 tribute to Marilyn Monroe, later reworked to honor Princess Diana—and situating it effectively into her own cinematic universe. It also places her in the lineage of these icons.
Unfortunately, such odd asides and weird lyrical turns are in relatively short supply on this outing. Aside from the title track, a comparatively weak number about suburban ennui that feels informed by streaming TV dramas such as “Big Little Lies,” the songs are mostly minor scenes about intense infatuation with few surprises. “Wild at Heart” and “Dark but Just a Game” are reasonably moody and tuneful but lyrically indistinct, which is not something you can say about most of her work.
The penultimate track, “Dance Till We Die,” opens with a line about Ms. Del Rey interacting with her idols: “I’m coverin’ Joni and I’m dancin’ with Joan / Stevie is callin’ on the telephone”—that would be Joni Mitchell, Joan Baez and Stevie Nicks—but it doesn’t build upon that memorable kickoff. The song serves mostly to set up the closing number, a cover of “For Free” from Ms. Mitchell’s 1970 LP “Ladies of the Canyon” that features singers Zella Day and Natalie Mering, who records as Weyes Blood.
Had it closed her previous release, “For Free” would have been a bold claim that the younger singer deserved to be mentioned in the same breath as one of her heroes. But here the gesture doesn’t feel earned, and the folky melody sounds almost medieval and hence out of place next to those crafted with Mr. Antonoff and Mr. Nowels. Ms. Del Rey set a high bar last time and “Chemtrails” can’t reach it—though the music here is strong and her voice has grown richer, the uncharacteristically vague lyrics fail to transport you to Ms. Del Rey’s usually immersive worlds.
—Mr. Richardson is the Journal’s rock and pop music critic. Follow him on Twitter @MarkRichardson.

title: Lana del Rey anuncia para junio su nuevo álbum “Rock Candy Sweet”
content:
Solo unos días después del lanzamiento de su último disco de estudio, Lana del Rey ha anunciado a través de su perfil de Instagram que el próximo 1 de junio verá la luz otro álbum suyo titulado “Rock Candy Sweet”, una “venganza” con la que según ella se resarcirá de las críticas recibidas en los últimos meses.
Respecto a ello, la artista estadounidense se ha hecho eco de manera irónica de un reportaje de la revista Harper’s Bazaar: “Solo puedo agradecer de nuevo artículos amables como este por recordarme que mi carrera se ha construido sobre la apropiación cultural y por hacer glamourosa la violencia de género”.
“Seguiré haciendo frente a ese tipo de ideas con mi próximo álbum”, ha señalado a continuación, añadiendo algo más de contexto sobre “Rock Candy Sweet” que, según sus palabras, será algo así como su “venganza” a las polémicas en las que tiende a verse envuelta por sus declaraciones.
Se refería por ejemplo a cuando meses atrás constató que había incluido gente afroamericana en la portada de su último disco en el mercado, en un intento por “anticiparse” a posibles críticas sobre inclusividad, algo que el artículo de Harper’s Bazaar consideró “innecesario”.
“Tienen razón, habría sido innecesario si nadie hubiera criticado significativamente todo sobre ese álbum para empezar. Pero lo hicisteis. Y quiero venganza”, ha apostillado en Instagram.
De cumplirse los plazos, “Rock Candy Sweet” verá la luz apenas dos meses después de la publicación este pasado viernes de su séptimo disco de estudio, “Chemtrails Over The Country Club”, en el que su música realiza un giro desde California hacia el interior de EE.UU.
De momento la crítica ha celebrado con efusividad su publicación, a la altura del previo “Norman Fucking Rockewell” (2019), que fue calificado como uno de los mejores discos de 2019 a nivel internacional.
Entre medias, la incansable artista editó “Violet Bent Backwards Over The Grass”, un audiolibro de poemas escritos por ella, y en agosto de 2019 lanzó de manera independiente el sencillo musical “Looking For America”, impulsada por los tiroteos en Estados Unidos.
Y es que desde el inicio de su carrera en 2012 como Lana del Rey con el exitoso “Born To Die” (antes había lanzado “Lana Del Ray” (2010) bajo su nombre real, Lizzy Grant), esta compositora e intérprete se ha mostrado muy activa en términos discográficos, con la publicación de prácticamente un disco cada uno o dos años.

title: Lana Del Rey vient de sortir Chemtrails Over The Country Club son nouvel album, elle annonce déjà le prochain
content:
Lana Del Rey vient tout juste de sortir son nouvel album Chemtrails Over The Country Club qu'elle annonce déjà le prochain. On vous en dit plus !
Justin Bieber a dévoilé vendredi son nouvel album Justice, dont nous vous avons fait la critique, mais ce n'est pas le seul ! Lana Del Rey est elle aussi de retour avec Chemtrails Over The Country Club. Ce septième opus comporte onze morceaux de pop épurée. On y retrouve des mélodies douces et enivrantes typiques de l'univers de la chanteuse. Dans cet album, Lana Del Rey évoque la difficulté en tant que femme de se faire une place dans le milieu de la musique mais également de manière générale. L'artiste avait déjà dévoilé plusieurs clips dont celui de "Chemtrails Over The Country Club" et "White Dress", offrant un avant-goût à ses fans.
Mais si Lana Del Rey ravit tout le monde avec ce nouvel album, elle surprend en annonçant déjà la sortie de son prochain ! Et c'est sur Instagram que la chanteuse a dévoilé l'information. Samedi, l'artiste a publié une photo avec en légende : "ROCK CANDY SWEET le 1er juin". Un projet qui lui tient à coeur puisque Lana Del Rey a indiqué dans ses stories que cet opus contiendrait ses réponses face aux "accusations d’appropriation culturelle et de glamourisation des violences domestiques" qui l'ont visées récemment. On a hâte de découvrir tout cela ! En attendant, détendez-vous en écoutant notre playlist des nouveautés de la semaine avec Justin Bieber, Jul et Naps, SCH...

title: Lana Del Rey, annunciata l'uscita di un nuovo album su Instagram
content:
A pochi giorni dall’uscita del suo “ Chemtrails over the Country Club ”, Lana Del Rey ha annunciato un nuovo album di inediti previsto per l’1 giugno 2021. Il titolo rivelato sui suoi canali social è “ Rock Candy Sweet ” e si tratterebbe di un nuovo disco di inediti. L’annuncio di “Rock Candy Sweet” è stato decisamente sobrio, con una foto che ritrae un primo piano dell’artista e il nome del disco. Nessun singolo, nessuna cover e nessuna notizia di qualsiasi genere su questo nuovo album, ad eccezione della data d’uscita. Probabilmente nelle prossime settimane se ne saprà di più ma al momento l’uscita di questo nuovo album è tanto misteriosa quanto inaspettata.
L’uscita di “Chemtrails over the Country Club” era prevista inizialmente per lo scorso anno. L’emergenza sanitaria ( LO SPECIALE - GLI AGGIORNAMENTI - LA MAPPA ) ancora in corso ha però costretto Lana Del Rey a rivedere i suoi piani e a posticipare il disco a marzo 2021. Ovviamente la stessa sorte è toccata al tour e ai concerti di presentazione di questo album che sono stati riprogrammati a data da destinarsi, quando la situazione sarà meno complicata. Tra i singoli estratti da“Chemtrails over the Country Club” troviamo “ Let Me Love You like a Woman ”, che ha visto la luce sulle piattaforme digitali a ottobre 2020. Il singolo omonimo rilasciato a gennaio di quest’anno e “ White Dress ” che ha accompagnato l’uscita dell’album lo scorso 19 marzo. Nel frattempo Lana Del Rey ha pubblicato la sua prima raccolta di poesie “ Violet Bent Backwards over the Grass ” ed è in attesa di pubblicare la seconda parte dell’opera “ Behind the Iron Gates – Insights from the Institution ”, prevista per il 2021. La cantante aveva annunciato anche l’uscita un disco di cover country ma, l’annuncio di “Rock Candy Sweet” sembra aver stravolto i programmi dell’artista che ha preferito “ripiegare” su un nuovo disco di inediti.
Le critiche dietro a “Chemtrails over the Country Club”
approfondimento
Lana Del Rey, il post prima dell'uscita del nuovo album
A poche ore dalla pubblicazione della copertina di “Chemtrails over the Country Club”, molte riviste di settore l’hanno etichettata come una delle più brutte cover di sempre. Inoltre l’artista è stata accusata di aver “coperto” le differenze tra le donne di colore e le donne bianche con l’uso del bianco e nero. Lana Del Rey ha risposto dicendo di essere sempre stata una persona attenta all’inclusione, nella vita come nella musica. Ha poi aggiunto che la foto voleva immortalare un momento di convivialità tra amiche, a prescindere dalle differenze e dal colore della pelle.
In un post sui social l’artista ha scritto: “Fate uno zoom, aguzzate bene lo sguardo: quelle sono le mie amiche nella vita reale e ce ne sono di tutti i colori. Vengono da ogni parte del mondo e hanno figli con persone di tutte le razze. Del resto nessuno di noi può dirsi di un’unica razza. Ho tanti problemi ma tra questi non c’è il razzismo”. Con queste parole Lana Del Rey ha messo a tacere la polemica, sottolineando il fatto che la foto voleva intendere l’esatto contrario di ciò che si è detto.

title: Lana Del Rey à meia-luz
content: Ao sexto álbum, Lana Del Rey surpreendeu. Depois de cinco discos entre o bom e o óptimo, deu-nos outra coisa, rara: Norman Fucking Rockwell! seria um clássico se os tempos ainda permitissem tais coisas. Nesse disco de 2019, a norte-americana dispensou os artifícios dos outros trabalhos seus e entregou-se à canção, orquestrada com inteligência e uma leveza pouco habituais. A beleza da música de Lana pôde aparecer inteira, sem manhas, solta do peso da mitologia que ela própria criou, sem armadilhas.

title: Neues Album von Lana Del Rey - Eine echt starke Sisterhood-Platte
content:
Neues Album von Lana Del Rey – Eine echt starke Sisterhood-Platte Auf «Chemtrails Over The Country Club» geht es mal wieder vor allem um die Künstlerin selbst. Na und? Joachim Hentschel
Vor knapp zwei Wochen stellte der Film-Stuntman Hunter Ray Barker in Los Angeles ein blaues Kinderplanschbecken vor dem «Los Toros» auf, seinem Lieblings-Mexikaner. Füllte es mit Kidneybohnen, liess sich für 24 Stunden in der Pampe nieder, um Spenden für das coronagefährdete Restaurant zu sammeln.
Und bekam nachmittags glamourösen Besuch. Die Sängerin und Songwriterin Lana Del Rey schaute vorbei, im roten Kapuzenpullover. Sprach ihre Solidarität aus und postete das Foto für ihre mehr als 18 Millionen Instagram-Fans. Unter das heitere Bild schrieb sie: «Don't ask why.» Fragt nicht nach dem Grund.
Abgesehen davon, dass sich Lana Del Rey in der Öffentlichkeit sonst von Bohnenzubereitungen aller Art weitgehend fernhält, ist der Nukleus der Geste ganz typisch für sie. Nehmt das Bild, so schäbig es ist, scheint sie hier zu sagen. Nehmt es für seine Aura, seine amerikanische Momentaufnahmenhaftigkeit, aber fragt nicht, was es bedeuten soll.
Lana Del Rey ist allerdings Entertainerin, schreibt Songs mit viel Text, hat gewaltige Erfolge. Und ihre Pop-Inszenierungen als frühe Joan Didion und noch frühere Lauren Bacall sind derart spektakulär und cineastisch, dass man kaum drum herumkommt, in ihnen auch immer die Geschichten zu suchen. Den erzählerischen Drive, den man eigentlich erwarten dürfen sollte, wenn jemand im kirschroten Mercedes-500-K-Cabrio durchs Video fährt.
Zuletzt hat Lana Del Rey versucht, sich in die Diversity-Diskurse einzuschalten.
Dennoch handle Lana Del Rey am Ende immer nur von sich selbst, sagen ihre Kritiker. Von sich und den alten, wasserdicht nostalgischen, vermeintlich entpolitisierten Bildern, die sie herunterblättere wie in einem Vintage-Style-Account auf Pinterest. Dass das freilich eine Frage des Blickwinkels ist, dass Del Rey wohl nie eine Chance hat, als grosse Gegenwartskünstlerin anerkannt zu werden, solange die Leute immer schon an ihrem Lipgloss abglitschen, ist eine andere Sache.
Auf «Chemtrails Over The Country Club», ihrem neuen, siebten Studioalbum, singt Lana Del Rey in der Tat vor allem von sich selbst. Es ist ihre Hybris-Platte, ihr «Ich knabbere schwer an meinem Ruhm»-Liederzyklus, ihr Abschiedsbrief an die Häschenphase der Karriere. Wie autobiografisch das im Einzelnen gemeint sein könnte, ist die mit Abstand ödeste Frage, die man ans Kunstwerk stellen kann.
Es wird viel gewispert
Als mittelgrosse, bereits spätsommerliche Inszenierung funktioniert «Chemtrails Over The Country Club» jedenfalls so luftabschnürend gut, dass man Del Rey sowieso jedes Wort glauben will, das sie ins starke, digital hochaufgelöste Laurel-Canyon-2021-Echo hineinwispert.
Amerikanisch durch und durch: Das Cover zum Album «Chemtrails Over the Country Club». Foto: Keystone
Und ja, es wird viel gewispert auf dem «Chemtrails»-Album. Allerdings schon im ersten Song «White Dress» auf so überaus unbescheidene, vorlaute Art, dass Lana Del Rey die Stimme buchstäblich überschnappt. Hier erzählt sie, begleitet von einer kleinen Nightclub-Combo, über die Berufsanfänge als Kellnerin, die es ins Musikbusiness verschlägt und sich dort derart in die Ereignisse verheddert, dass die Zeilen des Songs vor lauter Silben fast zu platzen drohen.
Die Schattenseiten des Ruhms
40 Minuten später, gegen Ende der Platte, wird sie in «Dance Till We Die» am dramaturgischen Scheitelpunkt ankommen, an dem nur noch die Flucht aus dem Alltag des Ruhms möglich erscheint. Sie tanzt mit Joan Baez, telefoniert mit Stevie Nicks. Covert mit den Sängerinnen Zella Day und Weyes Blood, superfrech und superschlüssig, das Stück «For Free», in dem Joni Mitchell 1970 über entfremdete Arbeit im Kulturgewerbe klagte. Die Musik ist durchweg sparsam, man hört die Fingerkuppen auf den Saiten, die leise knackenden Schlagzeuger-Gelenke. Beziehungsweise das, was die Felsen der Santa Monica Mountains davon zurückhallen lassen.
Zuletzt hat Lana Del Rey versucht, sich in die Diversity-Diskurse einzuschalten, hier doch noch Punkte zu holen, die ihr als ultraweisser Retro-Style-Ikone bislang verwehrt blieben. Es ging desaströs nach hinten los – was allein deshalb schade ist, weil sie «Chemtrails Over The Country Club» auch für sich allein hätte sprechen lassen können, als, siehe oben, wirklich starke Sisterhood-Platte. Dass diese Musik durch und durch weiss ist, wie das Kleid der Kellnerin, die Leinwand vor dem Filmstart oder eben die verdammten Kondensstreifen, ist ja alles andere als verwerflich. Solange sie so beweglich, anschlussfähig und nachhaltig atemberaubend ist, wie viele es der Künstlerin eh nie zugestehen werden.
